verses.text: The Song of Songs, which is Solomon's.
verses.comment: This superscription attributes the song to Solomon. Traditionally, Solomon is seen as the author or as the central figure in the poem. The title suggests this is the greatest of songs, often interpreted both as a love poem and as an allegory of God's love for His people.

verses.text: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth! For your love is better than wine.
verses.comment: The desire for intimate union can be understood as both the love between bride and bridegroom, and symbolically, as the longing of the Church or souls for intimate communion with God. Wine here symbolizes joy and celebration.

verses.text: Your anointing oils have a pleasing fragrance; your name is oil poured out; therefore the young women love you.
verses.comment: The comparison of the beloved's name to oil suggests an overflowing abundance of grace, prefiguring the way God’s name and presence are a blessing to His people. The mention of anointing hints at the messianic undertones, connecting to Christ, the 'Anointed One'.

verses.text: Draw me after you; let us run. The king has brought me into his chambers. We will rejoice and be glad in you; we will extol your love more than wine; rightly do they love you.
verses.comment: The call to be drawn and led into the king’s chambers is seen by many as a desire for union with the Lord, reminiscent of the soul being invited into the presence of God. The community’s rejoicing affirms the communal aspect of faith and worship.

verses.text: I am dark, but lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem, like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Solomon.
verses.comment: The bride’s self-description emphasizes humility and beauty coexisting. Darkness refers to sun-darkened skin, symbolizing suffering or labor, while beauty points to being chosen and beloved despite hardship—a theme echoed throughout Scripture regarding God’s people.

verses.text: Do not gaze at me because I am dark, because the sun has looked upon me. My mother’s sons were angry with me; they made me keeper of the vineyards, but my own vineyard I have not kept.
verses.comment: Here, the metaphor of vineyards highlights themes of neglect and inner beauty. The bride is set apart, possibly misunderstood or mistreated by others—paralleling the suffering servant motif. The vineyard is often a symbol of God’s people or one’s soul.

verses.text: Tell me, you whom my soul loves, where you pasture your flock, where you make it lie down at noon. For why should I be like one who veils herself beside the flocks of your companions?
verses.comment: The language of the shepherd and flock recalls God as shepherd (Psalm 23; John 10), expressing the soul's desire to be close to its beloved shepherd. The veiling may allude to separation or being misunderstood.

verses.text: If you do not know, O most beautiful among women, follow the tracks of the flock, and pasture your young goats beside the shepherds’ tents.
verses.comment: Here, an invitation is given to seek the beloved among the community of the faithful, emphasizing the importance of communal worship and guidance under appointed shepherds.

verses.text: I compare you, my love, to a mare among Pharaoh’s chariots.
verses.comment: Comparing the beloved to a prized horse highlights beauty, distinction, and strength. It recalls biblical imagery where God’s people are chosen and set apart as precious.

verses.text: Your cheeks are lovely with ornaments, your neck with strings of jewels.
verses.comment: Adornment and beauty evoke the splendor and dignity of God’s people, arrayed in spiritual beauty and holiness.

verses.text: We will make for you ornaments of gold, studded with silver.
verses.comment: The crafting of ornaments recalls the Church as the Bride beautifully adorned for her husband (see Revelation 21), portraying spiritual preparation and sanctification.

verses.text: While the king was on his couch, my nard gave forth its fragrance.
verses.comment: Fragrant nard is associated with lavish love and devotion, as Mary anoints Jesus’ feet. The imagery points to sacrificial love and worship.

verses.text: My beloved is to me a sachet of myrrh that lies between my breasts.
verses.comment: Myrrh, a precious spice used at Jesus’ birth and burial, subtly connects the beloved with Christ, foreshadowing themes of incarnation, sacrifice, and burial.

verses.text: My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms in the vineyards of En Gedi.
verses.comment: The reference to En Gedi, a place of lush beauty and life, emphasizes delight, healing, and refreshment found in true union with the beloved.

verses.text: Behold, you are beautiful, my love; behold, you are beautiful; your eyes are doves.
verses.comment: Dove-like eyes symbolize innocence, peace, and the Holy Spirit. Beauty is celebrated not merely physically, but as a reflection of inner purity.

verses.text: Behold, you are beautiful, my beloved, truly lovely. Our bed is green;
verses.comment: The verdant bed points to abundance and rest, echoing Psalm 23's imagery of green pastures—symbolic of spiritual nourishment and rest in God's presence.

verses.text: The beams of our house are cedar, our rafters are cypress.
verses.comment: Cedar and cypress suggest strength, durability, and beauty, often associated with the temple (1 Kings 5:8). The dwelling built together signifies the enduring communion between God and His people.
